Mar 1

Two Year Anniversary of the Most Underrated Fight in Basketball History

Before I get going with this piece, I just want to assure you that this is not a blog exclusively about professional basketball players fighting — although that’d be pretty dope — I will cover other topics soon, but these just happen to be the ideas I’ve had recently.

On March 1, 2015, there was a basque derby match-up in the Liga ACB in Spain. For those of you who don’t understand what derby means in that context, it’s just the European word for rivalry. The two teams involved in the basque derby are Laboral Kutxa Baskonia and Dominion Bilbao Basket (now known as Saski Baskonia and RETAbet Bilbao Basket for sponsorship reasons).

As the game was coming to a close Bilbao led 91–73 and Ben Hansbrough — yes, the Ben Hansbrough that’s Tyler Hansbrough’s younger brother — drove to the basket and finished a lay-up for Baskonia. There were only ten seconds remaining after that basket and Bilbao should’ve decided to dribble the clock out.

But instead, Bilbao decided to channel their inner Larry David and have the last word. They inbounded the ball and threw it ahead to Dejan Todorovic who decided to go in for an uncontested dunk. I don’t know much about Todorovic’s life, but it’s pretty safe to say this was one of the worst decisions of his life.

There’s a lot to point out about this fight. The first thing to point out is that Todorovic got called for a travel. Are you serious? You decide to ascend to Ricky Davis levels of on-court asshole behavior by going in for a dunk when your team clearly has the game won and your opponents weren’t defending but fuck it up by traveling?

The second thing to point out is that Tornike Shengelia responds very similarly to how DeShawn Stevenson responded to Ricky Davis, with violence being the answer. However, Shengelia’s violent response is to the highest level and I love it.

Shengelia did the right thing by initially fouling Todorovic for going in for that disrespectful dunk. Then when Todorovic tries to be a tough guy and shove Shengelia like he wants to fight him, we find out Todorovic is not a tough guy and did not actually want to fight Shengelia after he throws the most underrated punch in the history of professional basketball.

Look at how close Todorovic is pre-punch.

Now, look at how far away Todorovic is post-punch. Todorovic also looks ready to break into tears which is what happens to most people when they realize they are in a fight but don’t actually want to be in a fight.

Also look at the reaction of the arena employee on the left. He has that damn he really did that look on his face and can clearly sense that all hell is about to break loose.

All hell does end up breaking loose.

The benches cleared and the whole thing turned into a brawl with players spilling into the front row.

This is where we start to realize some other things to point out in this fight.

Another thing to point out in this fight is that there were two sets of brothers involved. The first set of brothers plays on the same team, the Diop brothers. Ilimane Diop and Mamadou Diop both played for Baskonia.

Ilimane, who will be in the upcoming 2017 draft, is a Senegalese Center and was heavily involved in the brawl.

You can see here that it took multiple teammates, fans and coaches to restrain him which makes sense since he’s 6 11 and 225lbs.

The second set of brothers is really the more interesting set of brothers in this fight. The Bertans brothers, Dairis and Davis (who now plays for the San Antonio Spurs), were involved but on separate teams. Davis played for Baskonia at the time and Dairis played for Bilbao.

The two even came face to face in the fight as Dairis, the older brother, came flying in ready to crack some skulls and Davis came over, attempting to break the whole thing up. Isn’t that supposed to be the other way around? The younger brother, Davis, is supposed to be reckless and the older brother, Dairis, is supposed to seek non-violent resolutions, right?

In this picture, though, they both look ready to swing at each other which would’ve seriously been the coolest thing since sliced bread. But instead, Dairis runs by his younger brother and decides to take a swing at Shengelia.

I’m pretty sure Dairis either completely missed or scratched his face with his fingernail. After this, Dairis fell and got attacked by I. Diop and Shengelia. This is where we can point out this whole fight was really a huge L for him and Todorovic.

What we can also point out was that this fight wasn’t an L for Shengelia. Shengelia was the winner here as he threw the one punch that I am truly begging an NBA player to throw. When a fake tough guy like Todorovic steps to you like that, just turn around and rock his fucking skull. Eat the fine and suspension, because not only do you expose the fake tough guy, but no other fake tough guys will ever mess with you again. For the rest of your career everybody will remember you as the guy who was willing to throw a punch during a game, so whenever somebody steps to you you’ll know they’re the real deal and some serious fisticuffs are about to go down.

Shengelia was also a winner because, after the fight, he went over and apologized to a child in the first row as he probably realized he put this kid in danger and that was never his intention.

Shengelia, Todorovic, twelve bench players and others were disqualified immediately for their involvement in the most underrated fight in basketball history. The Spanish Basketball Federation decided to suspend Shengelia for five games, Todorovic for four and fine Dairis Bertans and the Diop brothers 3,000 euros.

Shengelia’s career would’ve been a forgetful one if not for this punch. Now, he’ll always have a place in my heart.
